verses.text: When anyone brings a grain offering to the LORD, his offering shall be of fine flour. He shall pour oil on it and put frankincense on it.
verses.comment: The word for 'grain offering' is 'minchah' in Hebrew, traditionally rendered as 'meal offering' or 'grain offering.'

verses.text: He shall bring it to Aaron's sons, the priests, and he shall take from it a handful of the fine flour and oil, with all of its frankincense; and the priest shall burn this as its memorial portion on the altar, a fire offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Memorial portion’ refers to the part burned on the altar as a token for God.

verses.text: And what is left of the grain offering shall be for Aaron and his sons. It is a most holy part of the LORD's fire offerings.
verses.comment: 'Most holy' indicates it could only be eaten by male priests in a holy place (see Lev. 6:16-18).

verses.text: If you bring as a grain offering an offering baked in the oven, it shall be unleavened cakes of fine flour mixed with oil, or unleavened wafers smeared with oil.
verses.comment: 'Oven' refers to a clay oven used in ancient Israel. Unleavened meanings: bread without yeast.

verses.text: And if your offering is a grain offering baked on a griddle, it shall be of unleavened fine flour mixed with oil.
verses.comment: 'Griddle' is a flat baking pan (akin to a modern skillet).

verses.text: You shall break it in pieces and pour oil on it; it is a grain offering.
verses.comment: The breaking signifies preparation for offering; the oil for richness and dedication.

verses.text: And if your offering is a grain offering cooked in a pan, it shall be made of fine flour with oil.
verses.comment: 'Pan' here denotes a deeper vessel than the griddle (possibly a pot).

verses.text: You shall bring the grain offering that is made from these things to the LORD, and when it is presented to the priest, he shall bring it to the altar.
verses.comment: Faithfulness to word order; ‘presented’ means being handed over to the priestly service.

verses.text: And the priest shall take from the grain offering its memorial portion and burn it on the altar, a fire offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Pleasing aroma' is a standard phrase for offerings, indicating God's acceptance.

verses.text: But what is left of the grain offering shall be for Aaron and his sons; it is a most holy part of the LORD's fire offerings.
verses.comment: Repetition from verse 3 emphasizes the holiness and priestly privilege.

verses.text: No grain offering that you bring to the LORD shall be made with yeast, for you shall burn no leaven nor any honey as a fire offering to the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Leaven' (yeast) and 'honey' (perhaps fruit syrup) both ferment—symbolizing corruption or decay.

verses.text: As an offering of firstfruits you may bring them to the LORD, but they shall not be burned on the altar as a pleasing aroma.
verses.comment: 'Firstfruits' could be leavened (Lev. 23:17) but were not burned on the altar.

verses.text: You shall season every grain offering with salt. You shall not allow the salt of the covenant of your God to be lacking from your grain offering. With all your offerings you shall offer salt.
verses.comment: 'Salt of the covenant' refers to the enduring nature of God's promises.

verses.text: If you offer as a grain offering of firstfruits to the LORD, you shall offer for the grain offering of your firstfruits crushed new grain, roasted by fire, from fresh kernels.
verses.comment: Crushed, roasted 'new grain' refers to the earliest harvest, prepared simply.

verses.text: You shall put oil on it and lay frankincense on it; it is a grain offering.
verses.comment: Oil and frankincense mark the offering as sacred and pleasing.

verses.text: And the priest shall burn as its memorial portion some of the crushed grain and some of the oil, with all its frankincense. It is a fire offering to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Memorial portion’ repeats the core aspect: part burnt for God, part for the priest.
